title: Gaussian process toolkit for modelling the dynamics of transcriptional regulation

author: Pei Gao, School of Computer Science, University of Manchester

segmentation: Good afternoon and pick out from school of Computer Science, University of Manchester.

Today I'm going to talk about introduce our Gaussian Process Toolkit for modeling the dynamics of the transcriptional regulation with the application, especially for the inference of the transcription factor activity.

Firstly, I would like to give a short introduction about what problem I'm going to solve and the basic biological biological knowledge we need for this talk and the assumptions of our algorithms and the notations for this call extra and then in the next three sessions I'm going to introduce three different mathematical differential equation models for the transcription network and as well as three.
Different biological examples.
And after that short discussion and the future work will unmet today's presentation.

The problem we are going to solve, who is within the context of transcription regulation, the basic biological knowledge we are going to use is can be described as these three cartoons are different.
Transcription factor is a kind of protein which controls the gene expression when transcription factor is bound to the promoter region of a DNA, the gene expression will start to be activated.
Or Rip rest as you can see for this is the activation case when the transcription factor is bound to the gene.

The protein general translated from the M RNA, will the concentrations of the protein generated from the M RNA will increase in the other case for the repression case, the concentrations of this part will decrease.
That is the basic biological concept we're going to use, and from the biological experiment, some quantities can be easily measured in a high throughput manner.
For example, the M RNA concentrations with microarray but other quantities might be relatively hard to be measured.
For example, the protein concentration which is located in the nuclears.
Hence the aim of our work is to infer the transcription factor activity given the M RNA concentration of the target genes.
The challenges of this work is to provide a continuous time of the.
Inference given only a limited number of the opposition observations on the expression levels.

Hence, the central concept of our of these two kids is to use Gaussian process to define the prior distribution over the protein concentration and we developed a framework which can be used for both activation and repression cases.
